title: 103_s224
content: The "Enhanced Rescissions Act of 1993" allows for expedited consideration of certain proposed rescissions under the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974. The "Enhanced Rescissions Act of 1993" allows the President to propose rescinding budget authority provided in an appropriations Act. The President must transmit a special message to Congress within 3 days of an appropriation Act's enactment, proposing to rescind budget authority and including a draft bill. The special message must specify the budget authority to be rescinded and follow procedures for expedited consideration. The "Enhanced Rescissions Act of 1993" allows the President to propose rescinding budget authority provided in an appropriations Act. Each special message must specify the budget authority to be rescinded and follow procedures for expedited consideration in Congress. The majority or minority leader of the House of Congress where the appropriation Act originated must introduce the draft bill or joint resolution accompanying the special message within two days of receipt. If not, any Member of that House may introduce it on the third day. The bill or joint resolution will be referred to the Committee on Appropriations for reporting without substantive changes. The bill or joint resolution introduced in the House must be referred to the Committee on Appropriations, which must report it without substantive changes within seven days. If the committee fails to do so, it will be discharged, and the bill will be placed on the calendar for consideration. A final vote on the bill must be taken within 10 days of its introduction in the House. The bill or joint resolution introduced in the House must be referred to the Committee on Appropriations, which must report it without substantive changes within seven days. If the committee fails to do so, it will be discharged, and the bill will be placed on the calendar for consideration. A final vote on the bill must be taken within 10 days of its introduction in the House. If the bill or joint resolution is agreed to, it will be engrossed, certified, and transmitted to the other House of Congress on the same day. The Committee on Appropriations must report a bill or joint resolution without substantive changes within seven days of receiving it. If the committee fails to do so, it will be discharged, and the bill will be placed on the calendar for consideration. A final vote on the bill must be taken within 10 days of its introduction in the House. After a bill or joint resolution is agreed to in the House of Representatives or the Senate, the engrossed bill is returned to the originating House. A motion to proceed to consider a bill under this section in the House of Representatives is highly privileged and not debatable. Debate on a bill under this section in the House of Representatives is limited to 4 hours, divided equally between those in favor and those opposing the bill. Debate in the House of Representatives on a bill or joint resolution under this section is limited to 4 hours, divided equally between those favoring and opposing the bill. Appeals from decisions of the Chair regarding the Rules of the House of Representatives for a bill or joint resolution under this section are decided without debate. Consideration of a bill or joint resolution under this section is governed by the Rules of the House of Representatives. Debate in the Senate on a bill or joint resolution under this section is limited to 10 hours, with 1 hour for debatable motions or appeals. The majority leader and minority leader control the time equally. A motion to proceed to the consideration of a bill or joint resolution is privileged and not debatable in the Senate. Amendments to the motion are not allowed, and neither is a motion to reconsider the vote. The appeal time for a bill or joint resolution is limited to 1 hour, divided between the mover and the manager. The minority leader controls the time in opposition if the manager is in favor. Additional time can be allotted by the leaders during consideration. Amendments are prohibited for bills or joint resolutions under this section. No amendments allowed for bills or joint resolutions under this section. Budget authority proposed for rescission must be available for obligation after the bill is defeated. Definitions for appropriation Act and continuity of a session provided. The text discusses the continuity of a session of Congress and the rules regarding the transmission of special messages. It also amends Section 904 of the Act related to rulemaking powers. The text amends Section 904 of the Act related to rulemaking powers and makes conforming amendments to sections 1011 and 1015. The text amends Section 1015 of the Act by inserting new provisions and updating references to sections 1012, 1013, and 1014. The text includes amendments to Section 1016 of the Act, updating references to sections 1012, 1013, and 1014. Clerical amendments are made to the table of sections for subpart B of title X of the Act. "Section 1013: Expedited consideration of certain proposed rescissions."
